awd_titl_txt: AF:Small:Collaborative Research:Kinetics and Thermodynamics of Chemical Computation
awd_abstract_narration:
Biology is replete with smart molecular systems that perform nanoscale assembly, sense environmental stimuli, create chemical signals, and produce physical motion - each of these tasks coordinated by information processing circuits implemented with chemical reactions. Learning how to build artificial chemicals that compute autonomously in complex environments would bring about groundbreaking advances in manufacturing, chemical sensing, and medicine. The theory of computation has proven invaluable in enabling information processing in electronic man-made systems, and much-studied algorithms underlie the behavior of everything from communication networks to video games. However, a thorough understanding of the principles of chemical computation is still lacking. The goal of this proposal is to use rigorous mathematical models to investigate the capabilities and limitations of chemical information processing.

The proposed research will bring the fields of physics, chemistry, biology, and computer science closer intellectually and mutually enrich them. For example, conceptual frameworks and mathematical tools capturing the manipulation of information at the molecular level may yield critical insights into the design principles of evolved biological regulatory networks. Further, understanding how information processing is possible in the disordered world of chemistry could result in error-robust electronic computing. The project will also contribute to the development of undergraduate and graduate courses, which will train students to apply the principles of computer science and electrical engineering in traditionally incompatible domains. This will encourage the next generation of scientists to break through traditional disciplinary barriers and create the scientific and engineering fields of tomorrow. 

This proposal will answer foundational questions about the computational power of chemical kinetics (chemical reaction networks). How can chemicals be programmed to have desired behaviors? How much molecular energy does such computation consume? How much "more computation" does every additional chemical reaction enable? Recent advances in DNA nanotechnology (strand displacement cascades) demonstrate that molecular systems of complex functionality can be designed and constructed from the ground up. This proposal will help precisely delineate the capabilities and limitations of this technology, resulting in smaller, simpler DNA-based circuits. This proposal also introduces a new paradigm, based on the laws of thermodynamics, for programming DNA-DNA interactions. As chemical and biological systems are comprised of molecules that are inherently information-rich and programmable, principles of computer science will help design smart molecules.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

por.por_cntn:
Learning how to build artificial chemicals that compute autonomously in complex environments would bring about groundbreaking advances in manufacturing, chemical sensing, and medicine. The theory of computation has proven invaluable in enabling information processing in electronic man-made systems, and much-studied algorithms underlie the behavior of everything from communication networks to video games. However, a thorough understanding of the principles of chemical computation is still lacking. The larger goal of this proposal was to use rigorous mathematical models to investigate the capabilities and limitations of chemical information processing. Specifically, the major goals of this project were: 

(1) Answer foundational questions about the computational power of chemical kinetics (chemical reaction networks),

(2) advancing the theory and practice of DNA strand displacement cascade as a molecular primitive for realizing chemical reaction networks, 

(3) developing a theory for programming structure and behavior of strand displacement systems via programming two simple thermodynamic quantities (bonding and configurational entropy). 

 

Intellectual Merit:

The intellectual merit of this award was in advancing our understanding of computation as embedded in the chemical world. Over the lifetime of the award we achieved progress in all three major goals of the project:

In the context of the first major goal of this project (chemical reaction networks), we obtained a new error-correcting algorithm for the natural and useful problem of single-molecule detection. We also developed a new theory of how chemical reaction networks can be composed into larger networks, and proved fundamental limits on how efficiently chemical reaction networks can compute if the counts of all species are large.

In support of the second goal (DNA strand displacement cascade), the project helped fund the experimental demonstration of the first DNA-only oscillator. We also showed how spurious production of output in strand displacement cascades could be reduced by using logical redundancy. The project also helped fund the development of a new paradigm for "in memory" computation with information stored in DNA.

For the third goal (thermodynamic programming), we developed a software package to solve questions about thermodynamically stable configurations, proved that certain questions about thermodynamics are worst-case computationally difficult, and proposed a new way to create a catalytic chemical system with programmable energy barrier in the absence of the catalyst.

 

Broader Impact:

This project helped support four Ph.D. students, two of whom have recently graduated. One is a women now continuing postdoctoral work at UT Austin. Additionally the project supported the involvement of two undergraduate students in research, which resulted in a conference publication and a best paper award for the students. An undergraduate student was able to travel to an international conference and present a talk to a broad audience.

The work was disseminated to the broader community through published conference and journal papers. The results obtained were incorporated into the curriculum for two graduate-level courses.


Last Modified: 10/26/2020
Modified by: David Soloveichik
